turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: That would be even worse -- it would be a compromise.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Success or nothing?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No -- not even success.  My writing is not for making a living -- it's for living.  Not for other people, it's for me.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You work in the cemetery.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: A man must eat --  And drink.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: The <u>Castle</u> cemetery.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: -- I'm flattered, of course, to be considered a friend -- even without knowing all the details.  -- To see such determination is reward enough for me.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: The Kafka men are famous for it, you know.  Delivering meat barefoot in the depths of winter, picking up sacks of flour with their teeth --

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- Oh, yes, determination runs in the family.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: There is <u>one</u> thing I'd like you to tell me.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I'm trying to find things out myself -- that's the whole point.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: What made you think <u>I'd</u> be able to get you into the Castle?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: The cemetery is nearer the Castle than anywhere else -- wasn't it part of the Castle originally?  -- I always assumed there'd be a gate or something.  Isn't there?

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: In a manner of speaking.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: I was restoring some stones here in the upper section one day -- and I found this.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: An empty tomb?

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: A cenotaph -- a monument to someone whose remains ended up elsewhere. But look --

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: The Castle gates were blockaded in the time of the great plague -- it's an escape route.  Don't get stuck.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Not a chance.  I'm the thinnest person I know.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- You appreciate my writing.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Will you do me a favor then?

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Another one?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: If I don't see you later -- go to my house and find my notebooks -- and destroy them.  All my manuscripts -- just burn them. Please.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: What an extraordinary request!

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: It's my last and final one.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Then its authority is in doubt.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: A true friend would do it.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Not necessarily.  A <u>wife</u> would.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: The keeper of the files is still waiting for your final summation of the Erlanger claim.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I gave it to him yesterday.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: You didn't give it to <u>me</u>.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No, I left it in his office.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: Did you see him?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I've never seen him.  I don't believe there is a keeper of the files.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: He's usually in the storage room sorting things out.  He can't close the file on a case until he has the concluding report.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: He has it, he just hasn't noticed it yet, all right?

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: Who's to say he ever will?  He's a timid old man and quite careful not to tread on anyone's toes -- In fact, I'm the only one he trusts and he wouldn't even look at a document if it didn't first come through me.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: In an organization as efficient as ours, if a document once in a great while gets lost it might never be found at all.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Burgel, I thought it would be easier, as long as I was passing --

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: But <u>I'm</u> the messenger.  An error like this damages my credibility.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Your credibility -- yes, it's well known.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: When I deliver a message the very act of delivering it, you might say, gives it an official stamp, and only in this way are both the sender and the receiver satisfied that it was delivered at all.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I'll commit that to memory.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: Are you looking for Gabriela Rossmann?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: Good morning --  Or should I say good afternoon?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Say what you like -- no one pays the least attention.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: Oh, don't they?  I think you underestimate my station in this office and overrate your own.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Not today, Burgel.  Send one of your memos, write up one of your communiques, but for God's sake don't bother me today.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: It's my place to offer advice, not yours -- and by advising the Chief Clerk of your unpunctuality it's certainly not my situation that's compromised, if that's what you're implying.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You're just doing your job.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: It's what I'm paid to do.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You're detestable.

turns.speaker: BURGEL
turns.text: And you're late!

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You wanted to see me, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: Sit down, Kafka.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: You've been with the firm for nearly nine years.  You've done your work diligently, there are no complaints on that score.  But there's more to the job than the work -- there are other people to consider -- and frankly, Kafka, we eel your social situation could bear improving.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: ... My ... social situation?

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: You keep too much to yourself -- you're a lone wolf.  It makes me uneasy, and if it makes me uneasy I can't imagine the impression you make on lesser employees.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: To do my work well, I have little time for --

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: You must make the time.  Where do you go off to in the lunch hour?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I usually take lunch by the River.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: It's not healthy, Kafka -- not for you and not for your workmates.  At the annual dinner this month you again failed to make an appearance.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I did not realize it was obligatory.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: Have you never wondered -- and I mention this only in passing --  why other clerks have advanced to more responsible positions while you, who have been here longer, have not?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: Attitude, Kafka.  It doesn't matter how well you do your work -- you still see it as something to be gotten on with rather than something to take an active interest in.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Well, I --

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: Oh, I know you got along with that poor fellow -- what was his name?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- Eduard --

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: -- Yes -- Raban -- but he was too much like you -- even more so perhaps.  He wasn't here as long as you, so I didn't know him as well -- but I could see the influence he was having.  I simply want you to be aware of this because you'll be happier for it.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: I understand you fancy yourself an author.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: In a small way.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: You might find a more athletic hobby -- put some color in your cheeks.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Excuse me, sir -- I understand you have Eduard Raban's file.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I wonder if I might look to see if there's an address for family -- I thought I'd like to write to them.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: Was there something else?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No -- I just -- I feel a sense of obligation.  He was my friend -- if I can be of any help -- closing his affairs.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: No, there's only one report to complete.  I'll be doing it myself and submitting it to the Castle today or tomorrow.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I see -- it's just the Erlanger claim then.

turns.speaker: CHIEF CLERK
turns.text: The <u>Orlac</u> claim.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Sorry, yes -- well -- thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I'm Kafka -- I work upstairs in Accident --

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You're a friend of Eduard Raban's.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Why would you suppose so?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Oh -- well, I thought he once mentioned --

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: One of you must be mistaken.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I'm sorry, but I just wondered --

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Excuse me, I have to copy this for Central Docketing by 2:30.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Hello again.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I've never seen you here before.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Have you looked?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Well -- nice to know life exists outside the office.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I was having an affair with Eduard.  He didn't tell you?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: He would have.  You were his best friend.  A better friend than me.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I suspected that he -- well.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: That he was -- satisfied in that regard.  I didn't want to pry.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: It's not that we wanted to deceive anyone -- but you know how these things are looked upon at the office.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: What's funny?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: This morning it was suggested to me that my own sense of office fellowship could bear improving.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: As long as it's on their terms. If your work and your private life don't correspond to their specifications you're labelled a dangerous agitator -- with no recourse whatsoever.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: How long were you and Eduard --

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Two or three months, that's all.  -- I seduced him.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No, I don't.  I'm amazed that anyone is able to bear life with any assurance at all.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Eduard didn't see it as something that needed bearing.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: The police would know the difference, wouldn't they?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Do you think people in the New Town care what happens over here?  This will always be the ghetto.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: He wasn't robbed.  He was identified by his wallet.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: And you believe everything the authorities tell you.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: When I have no reason to doubt.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: The very fact that they're authorities should give you reason. People will do anything to protect their own interests.  For all you know he was killed at the <u>hands</u> of the police.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- What could he have done to warrant that?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Are you free tonight?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Tonight?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: There are some people I'd like you to meet.  Can you come to the Musil district at eight o'clock?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: ... All right.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You almost married recently, didn't you?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Last year.  I -- it was broken off.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Eduard wanted to marry me.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: And you ...?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I'm suspicious of men who want to marry.  I believe they think it's the only thing that will make them equal to their fathers.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- I don't know the Musil district.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You won't have any trouble finding it.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Ah -- we're back to the "authorities" you spoke of.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: They're ubiquitous.  What we try to do ... is make them a little less so.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I nominated you as a possible candidate.  You were Eduard's good friend.  He read me some of your work.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I've hardly published enough for anyone to draw conclusions from.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You strike me as a man with a defined notion of injustice -- a high concern for the lot of your fellow men.  And yet you're able to remain an outsider.  With the concomitant air of ... superiority?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: The day he died, Eduard was called up to the Castle.  Did you know that?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: What of it?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: He was summoned to help correct a minor discrepancy of some sort in the Medical Records Division. Apparently one of his claims was relevant.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: And you still maintain -- what? That he was murdered.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: He was murdered.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You're shocked at the thought of Eduard tossing a bomb through a window.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I have no right to be, I know.  My experience with real life  is practically nil.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: When you only see someone sitting at a desk all day, it's liable to create a false impression.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: People must think the same of me -- a quiet, dependable person.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You think what we're doing is so wrong?  And what are you doing? Pursuing goodness?  For what?  To answer to some supreme tribunal?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: My only concern is the human tribunal.  Isn't it yours?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Yes -- which is why "quiet, dependable people" have to take charge of their own lives.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: At the cost of others?  You accuse people of murder without trial -- apparently without irony.  Did you go to the Castle with Eduard?  Then you have no idea what really might have happened that night at all -- even before or after he got there.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I'm collecting Eduard's things. If there's anything you want, take it or I'll give it to charity.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Burgel gave me this -- what does it mean?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Burgel! -- I didn't leave it with him.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Why were you given notice?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: They're not obliged to tell.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: It couldn't be for that incident with Burgel the other day.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Of course it could -- Burgel's been trying to get me thrown out as long as I can remember.  <u>He</u> could've killed Eduard.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You don't believe that.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I wouldn't put it past him.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: You might think -- I thought so myself at first -- that Burgel's too insignificant to be dangerous. But that's the very reason to beware! It's the small men to watch out for -- the ones who substitute method for character.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Now you've fallen into his trap. When he goes to bed at night Burgel dreams of inspiring as much fear in others as they inspire in him.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: It's still easier for you to understand suicide, isn't it.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: That street down there -- I always used to call it the approach road for suicides.  It leads straight down to the bridge and the River.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Burgel hated Eduard.  And me.  I'm sure he knew about us -- and I'm sure it drove him mad.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Burgel doesn't like anybody!

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: He used to like me -- very much more than I liked him.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: He's jealous, yes, but <u>that</u> jealous?  He's too cautious.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Of course he is -- the Castle precincts are not the safest part of the city after dark.  People disappear up there regularly.   If you want to lie in wait for someone, that's the place to do it.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Now you're saying Eduard was lured there?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: How often does one of our clerks have business in the house of records?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I've heard of it happening.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: And Burgel is the bringer of messages, isn't he?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Usually.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Or what if there really <u>was</u> an error? -- I don't know what kind -- any kind that needed correcting -- and what if Burgel was responsible for it?  One mistake -- even a small one in a firm like ours -- it could cost him a promotion.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: First these nameless authorities were the root of all evil, now it's insignificant Burgel.  If indeed there was a mistake -- and a minor one at that -- you're suggesting someone went to a lot of trouble over something so trivial as to not matter at all.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: What seems important to these people is not determined by the amount of work it entails -- you're far from understanding the authorities if you believe that.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Now Burgel's one of the authorities?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Gabriela! -- you did get away.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I knew you walked this way to work.  I wanted to find you before they did.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- I've just come from the Castle.  It's over.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Over?  It's only over when you can crawl to a clean little spot on earth where the sun sometimes shines and you can warm yourself a bit.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Gabriela ...?

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Should I tell you why I joined our late lamented nihilists? Why I became a murderer? Because murder ... is bliss.  It's easier than you might think to absorb and assimilate Evil -- once you've adopted its procedure.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Only two steps back?  Even the man they left to guard me retreated further than that.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I -- I found your jailer.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: This is the result of their elixir of youth.  They were to come and check on it during the night.  I contrived to miss the appointment.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: They're dead now.  We can get help.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I know how they reward failure. If they saw this I'd be rotting in the quarries by the afternoon -- with all the others.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: There's a new potion -- he said it was perfected.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I know there is.  And you're what I have to bargain with. For now you're the last one in their way.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I told you, they're <u>dead</u>.  It's finished.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: Why should I believe a man who never believed me?  They're absolutely right, you know -- guilt should never be doubted. It's easier that way.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I think you've just escaped for the moment.  Just as I did.  As Eduard did.  As they let us do. But only for the moment.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No -- not this time.

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I know better than you what people will say when they have to.  When they brought me in for questioning I informed on my friends the very first day.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- Listen to me --

turns.speaker: GABRIELA
turns.text: I do.  Always.  You understand the world better than any of us, Kafka.  And what it's becoming.  I've always held you in the highest regard.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Kafka -- is that your real name?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Yes.  Yes, of course -- why wouldn't it be?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: When was the last time you saw Mr. Raban?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Wednesday.  We left the office together.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Did you go anywhere afterwards -- to have a drink perhaps?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No, we said goodbye outside the building.  He went off, as usual, toward his house.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Your office is the Workmen's --

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- Accident and Compensation Association.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Where you've been employed for seven years.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Eight -- and seven months.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Engaged in the manufacture and distribution of ... pills and so forth.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Well -- other departments are, yes.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Would you describe your relationship with the dead man as close?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Yes.  Since he came to the office, almost three years ago, we've been quite good friends.  How was Eduard ...

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: He was found in the River.  Could he swim?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Was he depressed?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No.  He didn't seem to be.  Do you think he drowned himself?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Grown men don't normally fall into the river, do they?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: No, I suppose not.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: He might have had a drink or two, despite what you think.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Can I ask -- how you found me?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: His landlady knew of no other friends to refer us to.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I don't think he really had any. He had no family either.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: We know that.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: He wasn't a lonely man, though.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What makes you think so?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: ... Just a perception.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Probably not.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: Anyway, I'd like you to reflect that in me you have -- I won't say a friend, because we're complete fencers, of course -- from distinctly incompatible social classes -- but to some extent, shall we say, an interested third party.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I'll bear that in mind.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: -- Should you happen upon anything that might be relevant.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: But that's just my point -- she was more than upset, she was livid. She slammed every door on her way downstairs -- except that one.  I was just behind her and I didn't even hear that one <u>shut</u> -- not at all.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: That's not what I call conclusive evidence of an abduction.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: If someone was waiting here in the hallway to spirit her away, wouldn't they have shut the door as quietly as possible?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You told me to contact you if anything relevant came up -- Gabriela is relevant.  When I spoke to you before I didn't know she'd been seeing Eduard.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: That's been noted.  But where does it lead us?  Unless you have something more to add.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: She's missing.  I went to her house and she hadn't returned there.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Maybe it's true then what she said.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR
turns.text: What did she say?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: That the police may have allegiance to something other than truth.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: We saw her naked once -- didn't we.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I didn't realize you'd been here that long.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: You mean because it's been a while since there was a sunny day?  What a good detective you are.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: -- I was just trying to finish some work!

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You mean you've actually begun some?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: I can't make a simple statement without him taking issue with it

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- You should meet my father.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: For all your incompetence I was beginning to think you were at least loyal to me.  You're very good ham actors.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: -- Just doing our job.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: It's a farce.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: Still, we're probably closer to you at the moment than any of your fellow human beings.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Close only by virtue of antithesis.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: My assistants.  I should have known. Nothing is given to me.  I have to acquire everything.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: It's all right to be sarcastic in private to us -- because we have a sense of humor -- but when we're up at the Castle we suggest you don't make a fuss.  It would spoil the not unfavorable impression you make in other respects.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: ... Why take me into your confidence?

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: That's obvious, isn't it?  We have an opening for a new member.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: That's <u>mad</u>.

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: -- Oh, yes, it's mad.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- You said so yourself the firm is large and powerful.  If the discrepancy really was something big, Eduard's responsibility would still have to be small.  No poor young <u>clerk</u> could find himself in such a fix.

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: When a scapegoat is needed, my friend ...

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: Why are you so aggressively unimaginative?  Eduard is no longer the only casualty.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Then why haven't I been --

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: -- Gabriela, on the other hand, had made an enemy of this man Burgel.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Oh, Burgel!  Gabriela was having an affair with Eduard.  They were both members of <u>this group</u>.  If any crime's been discovered and people are paying for it, I'd look to <u>yourselves</u>!

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: The loyal civil servant.  I suppose you'll deny that shortchanging the workers to whom compensation is due is standard company policy.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: ... A piece of paper ...

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: A mere slip.  Your friend Mr. Raban dealt only with claims that came <u>in</u>, another department being responsible for compensation that goes out -- this is correct?

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: Through a very unfortunate -- and I might add extremely rare -- mishap, a document intended for the one department was sent to the other.  And for the first time -- though your friend wasn't aware of it -- two and two could have been put together to make one.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: ... A piece of paper ...

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: You see, Kafka, in all cases relating to the factory at Orlac -- which is what this paper referred to -- the authority that puts in a request and the authority that grants it is, to all intents and purposes, the same authority.

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: -- You seem amused.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: It only amuses me in that it gives me an insight into the ludicrous bungling that in some circumstances may decide the life of a human being.

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: -- If an obscure official up there in the distant mountains so far away from civilizing influences happens to meet with an unfortunate accident -- and should he tragically die in spite of the District Medical Officer's strenuous efforts to save him -- the firm wants to see the next of kin pacified and the disposition of the remains handled with the greatest possible ... efficiency.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: "Accident and Compensation" -- no one can accuse the firm of not supplying exactly what it promises.

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: I believe we've exceeded his expectations.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I had the grandest of financial plots in mind, the most malevolent of personal motives, conspiracy theories extending to every ... authority I could see.  And I find you.  A body snatcher.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: And I suppose Dr. Murnau didn't die in a cave-in.  You killed him to free the Position of Orlac Medical Officer for your own ends.

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: Yes, well -- we're looking for a new village now.  If we stay too long at one source ... people become suspicious.

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: May I ask where your two warders are?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Lying in the gutter where they belong.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: The fact that it's live bodies you practice your trade on doesn't seem to matter to you.

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: On the contrary, it matters a great deal.  We're engaged in immensely important research here.  I'm a revolutionary too, you know -- but a much more pragmatic one.

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: -- And the new patients they bring me aren't usually as dexterous as you've been in evading us.  Not perfect specimens by any means, but not the type of person who'll be missed either.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: What have you done with Gabriela Rossmann?

turns.speaker: MURNAU
turns.text: As a matter of fact you've caught us in a state of considerable excitement.  Our latest preparation we believe -- we pray -- is perfected. It should take years off her.

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: "Raban" -- that'll be nearly at the back of the alphabet.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: It usually is.

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: I'm not obliged to give you access, you know -- not without authorization -- but I'll make an exception this one time.

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: I'm overworked as it is.  "Raban" did you say?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Yes.  Isn't it there?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: Wait a minute.  "Raban?"  Where have I heard that name?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: He's the clerk who died last week. From the insurance department

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: Why would we keep files on <u>dead</u> employees?  All old files are sent up to the Castle.  Do you think we have room for two hundred years worth personnel records?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: It's gone out so quickly?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: Whenever an employee departs, shall we say, it's up to the head of his department to requisition his file, reassign any outstanding claims, and send it off.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- You mean my Chief has it.

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: If it was Accounts you wanted why did you ask for Employees?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Orlac is an account?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: It's a factory in the northern mountains.  One of our best customers.  Without a proper request I'm not obliged to do this, you understand -- but I'll make an exception on this one occasion.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: All these in the last year?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: You must have read about it in the papers -- there was a terrible cave-in.  It wouldn't have been so bad, but even the Medical Officer for the district was killed!

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I did read that.  They gave him a posthumous medal.

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: Dr. Murnau was the bravest of men. He spent an entire career in those backwaters with no regard for personal gain.  A great loss.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: This is the cross-reference of clerks who've worked on Orlac claims?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: Is your friend's name among them?  Then he only worked on the one case.  Your Chief will send me the final summation when he's finished with it.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Once a file's been sent to the Caste, is it possible to recall it for review?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: Of course not.  Only by a Director of the firm.  Who'd want to let in all kinds of riff-raff off the streets?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: What good are records if they're not open for public inspection?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: These laws have been with us for centuries -- how can you doubt them?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: What if I petitioned one of the Directors?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: You do not summon them -- they summon you -- and this, of course, hardly ever happens, if at all. The Directors are an eccentric lot and by nature cautious.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Where do our records go to in the Castle?

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: We're a medical firm, aren't we? They go to the Medical Records Section.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I could always apply there.

turns.speaker: KEEPER
turns.text: It so happens, my dear simple sir, that the Head of Medical Records at the Castle <u>is</u> one of the Directors of this firm.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: Ludwig.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: Oskar.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: He can't sit still.  Just when we arrive at a nightclub he wants to go to another one.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: You look tired.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: Gabriela Rossman was here looking for you.  Do you know her?

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: Women are all you have on your mind!

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: She went to the roof to sunbathe one lunch hour -- we watched her changing.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: They keep switching us from department to department.  He doesn't mind because he can't sit still.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: We used to be in the supply section, carrying boxes of medicine about but we dropped too many of them.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: It's not too bad working here.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: It's not our fault.  We're naturally nervous.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: And we're upset too.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: We've been together too long.  His personality is overflowing into mine and vice versa.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: -- How would <u>you</u> like to be in a horrible situation like that?

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: But your goal is so hard to reach. Do you think the official network would surrender to one man?  We would never think of attempting anything remotely as difficult.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: My mother used to tell us of the young man who decided to ride to the next village and how she was afraid that -- not even mentioning accidents -- the span of a normal happy life might fall far short of the time needed for such a trip.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: Oskar!

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: Ludwig?

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: This is filed incorrectly!

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: Here too!  They're all in a dreadful muddle!

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: We could go back to the office. Explain ourselves to the Chief Clerk.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: They'd drive us away.  That Kafka's made things very hot for us.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: I understand he was wounded in the lung.

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: It doesn't matter.  It's too late for all of us.

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: What's to become of us now?

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: Then that's the place for us!

turns.speaker: LUDWIG
turns.text: Amerika for us!

turns.speaker: OSKAR
turns.text: Amerika!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Hi - Carl Denham. I'm A big admirer of your work, sir. I've loved all your discoveries. I really want to work closely with you on this incredible find. It'll be good for you and good for me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Look Mr Denham - you're not welcome here. Just pack up your cameras and go.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'm coming onboard! Throw down a ladder!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: You're outta your depth here, Miss Darrow!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: There's no hard feelings, Mr Denham! I just want to come to the island with you!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Does this look like the "Queen Mary"?? We don't take passengers! Full steam ahead, Captain Engelhorn!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Can I see the map? My father spoke of references to a Beast God ...

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Kong is a myth, nothing but a native superstition, Miss Darrow. All we're going to find on that island are some primitive people in grass skirts. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm trying to reduce my handicap.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: I hope it fits ... Mrs Denham's a big lady.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It's ... lovely.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Miss Darrow ... I've been thinking. I would very much like to dedicate this motion picture to the memory of your father. It's a great shame he wasn't able to join us on this adventure. Truly a wonderful man.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: I thought that with your assistance we could have the premiere at the Albert Hall. We'll take out a full page ad in Variety - "The Lord Darrow Benefit screening". We'll invite the King of England - hell, we'll get the whole Royal Family along! It'd be good for them and good for us!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: To be quite honest, Mr Denham ... I find the whole idea to be quite reprehensible.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Am actually laying my hand on the twenty-five foot gorilla.Ladies and gentlemen! I am touching the beast!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Take your filthy paws off him -you ignorant pig!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Get the hell out of here.''!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Now Ann ...

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: What have you got there?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: A Neolithic bronze ... Reminiscent of the Nias Island cultures ... It ' s very curious. Defiantly Pagan. The use of ivory for the spear is quite unique ... What do you think?

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: I think you're trying to run before you can walk, Ann.

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: Now look at this fine example of early Hindu art ... I don't recall any sketches of this passing across my desk ...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I photographed it extensively, father.

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: Photography teaches you nothing, Ann! Click! One second and you've seen all you're going to see. I want you sitting here with your paper and pencils ... I want to see every chisel mark reproduced with painstaking accuracy. Understand the carving and you will understand the people! That Ann, is the key to archaeology.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Father!

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: These are priceless artifacts! They're ruining the site!

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: Out! Out! All of you! We have been issued with an exclusive permit -

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Father ... Father!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Father It's somewhere south-west of here - we need to inform the museum ...  organize an expedition -

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: All in due course, Ann. Our first responsibility is to get these artifacts safely back to London.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh God, it's that bloody yank!

turns.speaker: LORD DARROW
turns.text: Now now, Ann! Try be to polite.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He's grubbing for money, father.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I just wanna deal with the boss, ok?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, it's not ok! We're not about to be robbed blind by some two-bit hustler on the make!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You - calling me a thief? Well, that's great, coming from a glorified grave robber! You break into the tomb of some dead Egyptian - the poor guy's happily enjoying the afterlife when suddenly his shit gets stolen by a bunch of light fingered limeys!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Tell me, Mr Driscoll - is it a requirement of the forestry business that you have to be as thick as the trees you cut down?
